diagnoses: Leukemia (e.g., Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia, Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Bacterial infection (e.g., streptococcal or staphylococcal infection)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) associated with COVID-19
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Vitamin B Deficiency (specifically B2, B6, B12)
Drug reactions (e.g., drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome)
Viral exanthems (e.g., Enterovirus or Adenovirus infection)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reactions (e.g., Drug Rash with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms [DRESS] syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Hemolytic Anemia due to autoimmune disorder
Schizophrenia (in the context of multi-system disease)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as discoid rash, synovitis, seizures, proteinuria, and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD can present with a combination of signs and symptoms seen in various other connective tissue diseases like SLE, including synovitis, rash, and potentially pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: While RA is primarily known for joint inflammation and damage, systemic manifestations can include pericardial effusion and, in rare cases, seizures.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: A specific form of kidney involvement in systemic lupus erythematosus, presenting with proteinuria and potentially associated with other SLE symptoms such as seizures.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This condition often occurs in people with systemic autoimmune conditions like SLE and can lead to seizures. It can also be accompanied by proteinuria, though discoid rash and synovitis are less typical.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Although rare, in severe cases, Sjögren’s might contribute to kidney dysfunction (proteinuria) and might coexist with systemic symptoms due to its autoimmune nature.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting skin and muscles, dermatomyositis can have systemic effects including those resembling the symptoms listed, particularly rash.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis can have wide-ranging effects on the body, including skin manifestations (rashes), kidney dysfunction (proteinuria), and in rare instances complications that might lead to seizures.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: There are several types of vasculitis, diseases characterized by inflammation of blood vessels, which could potentially explain the combination of symptoms, particularly if nervous system or renal involvement is present.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Diseases (e.g., Endocarditis, Viral infections)
diagnoses.rationale: Certain infections can mimic autoimmune conditions, leading to a diverse range of symptoms including rashes, seizures, and organ inflammation, such as pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) can lead to a wide range of manifestations including Lymphadenopathy, potentially involved in inflammation processes causing periodontal disease, and has been associated with dysmenorrhea. Additionally, lupus patients are at an increased risk for pneumonia due to both the disease itself and the immunosuppressive drugs often used for treatment.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease that often presents with periodontal disease due to xerostomia (dry mouth) and can cause lymphadenopathy. It may overlap with conditions causing postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) and dysmenorrhea due to systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily a connective tissue disorder, Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes (EDS) can present with a wide array of symptoms including dysmenorrhea and can be associated with conditions like postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS). It does not directly cause pneumonia or Lymphadenopathy, but its systemic nature means multiple organ systems can be affected.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behçet's Disease is a rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. It can lead to symptoms like mouth sores simulating periodontal disease, and might be related to dysmenorrhea. It is less commonly associated with POTS or Pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Rheumatoid Arthritis is an autoimmune disease that can cause periodontal disease due to chronic inflammation. It might also lead to Lymphadenopathy. There are less direct associations with dysmenorrhea, pneumonia, or POTS.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis involves the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells in different parts of the body, including lymph nodes, which explains the lymphadenopathy. It can also indirectly affect menstruation and has been reported to cause POTS in some cases.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV infection compromises the immune system, making individuals more susceptible to infections like pneumonia. It also can cause Lymphadenopathy as a sign of immune system activation. HIV can indirectly affect menstrual cycles but is less directly related to POTS or periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
diagnoses.rationale: These conditions can cause systemic symptoms such as Lymphadenopathy. There are reports of associations with periodontal disease due to inflammation. Dysmenorrhea is also a common complaint, but connections to POTS are more circumstantial.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.rationale: Fibromyalgia is a chronic pain syndrome commonly associated with various systemic symptoms, including dysmenorrhea. Its association with POTS is also well documented, though it is less directly related to the other conditions.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Lyme disease can cause POTS, and in its chronic state, might present with symptoms such as Lymphadenopathy. It's more indirectly related to the other symptoms but remains a possibility in endemic areas.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms such as dry eyes and can potentially lead to more severe complications including organ involvement. Dry eyes are a hallmark of this condition.

diagnoses.name: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: Characterized by patterns of hyperactivity, impulsivity, and inattention that are pervasive, impairing, and inconsistent with developmental level. While not directly related to other symptoms, its presence can exacerbate or complicate other conditions.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when the body lacks sufficient iron to produce hemoglobin, leading to hypoferritinemia among other signs. It can contribute to fatigue, exacerbating hyperactivity symptoms indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Acute Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: An infection of the middle ear, which can occur in the context of various systemic conditions, or as a frequent childhood problem. Not directly related to the rest of the symptoms but common in occurrence.

diagnoses.name: Osteoporosis/Osteopenia
diagnoses.description: A condition of reduced bone mass or density, which can be secondary to several diseases or nutritional deficiencies, including those affecting calcium, vitamin D, or overall nutrition.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency
diagnoses.description: Characterized by an increased susceptibility to infections, including otitis media, and can lead to complications such as osteopenia due to chronic inflammation or malabsorption syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can cause a variety of systemic symptoms, including osteopenia and dry eyes (as part of secondary Sjögren's syndrome). Not typically associated directly with hyperactivity or hypoferritinemia.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Can cause systemic symptoms including osteopenia due to malabsorption, and iron deficiency anemia, leading to hypoferritinemia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Can lead to a multitude of systemic effects including mineral and bone disorder (which can manifest as osteopenia), and anemia due to decreased erythropoietin production, potentially affecting ferritin levels.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: The overproduction of thyroid hormones can lead to symptoms such as hyperactivity. Additionally, it can affect bone metabolism, potentially leading to osteopenia, and has been associated with ocular symptoms including dry eyes.

diagnoses: Autoimmune disorders such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: Can cause lymphadenopathy, dyspnea, and neurological symptoms that might mimic obsessive-compulsive behavior. Rarely, it can also lead to hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: A type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, causing lymphadenopathy. Some types can affect the central nervous system indirectly causing psychological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reason: Can cause lymphadenopathy, dyspnea with normal PFTs due to involvement of the lung's interstitial tissue, and neurosarcoidosis could potentially manifest as psychiatric symptoms.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reason: Can cause lymphadenopathy, and in later stages, affect the brain leading to behavioral changes. It can also indirectly cause hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus Type 1
diagnoses.reason: Primarily presents with hypoglycemia but can also cause dyspnea. Autoimmune association could potentially link to other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.reason: Can cause hypoglycemia and due to adrenal insufficiency, could indirectly lead to both psychological symptoms and dyspnea.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily a cause of hyperthyroidism, can sometimes present with hypoglycemia. Autoimmune involvement might link to other systemic symptoms including lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Psychiatric Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Various psychiatric conditions can manifest with obsessive-compulsive behavior; the physical symptoms might be either secondary or unrelated.

diagnoses.name: Insulinoma
diagnoses.reason: A tumor of the pancreas that causes excessive production of insulin, leading to hypoglycemia. The other symptoms are less directly related but could be consequent to systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reason: Can cause lymphadenopathy and dyspnea. In advanced cases or in association with HIV, it might indirectly affect blood sugar levels and mental health.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of rare blood disorders characterized by the overproduction of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, in the bone marrow. It can lead to organ damage, increased susceptibility to infection, and may present with gastroesophageal reflux due to associated gastrointestinal symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Esophagitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic/immune condition where eosinophils build up in the esophagus, often causing difficulty swallowing, gastroesophageal reflux disease symptoms, and food getting stuck. It is also associated with other hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease where stomach acid or, sometimes, stomach content, flows back into the esophagus, irritating its lining. GERD can make individuals more prone to respiratory infections.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: Also known as hay fever, it can cause a variety of symptoms including hypersensitivity reactions. It is associated with eosinophilia and can exacerbate or be associated with gastroesophageal reflux in some individuals.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your airways narrow and swell and produce extra mucus. It can lead to increased susceptibility to infections. Eosinophilia is a common finding in certain types of asthma, and GERD may worsen asthma symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders where the immune system’s ability to fight infectious disease is compromised or entirely absent. Increased susceptibility to infection is a major symptom, and some disorders may be associated with eosinophilia and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, it's a form of vasculitis that can cause eosinophilia, gastrointestinal symptoms like GERD, and hypersensitivity reactions including asthma.

diagnoses.name: Parasitic infections
diagnoses.description: Several parasites lead to eosinophilia and increased susceptibility to infections. Certain parasites can also cause gastrointestinal symptoms, including GERD.

diagnoses.name: Cystic Fibrosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects mostly the lungs, but also the pancreas, liver, kidneys, and intestine. It can lead to increased susceptibility to lung infections. Gastroesophageal reflux disease is a common complication.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food. It can cause various symptoms including eosinophilia, hypersensitivity reactions, and can worsen or mimic symptoms of GERD.

diagnoses.name: Pendred Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder leading to congenital hearing impairment, goiter, and in some cases, thyroid dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A chromosomal disorder in females that can lead to delayed puberty, hearing problems, and in some cases, heart issues.

diagnoses.name: Treacher Collins Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition affecting the development of bones and other tissues of the face, sometimes associated with hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Klinefelter Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic condition affecting males, caused by an extra X chromosome, leading to hypogonadism, which might cause delayed puberty, and can be associated with various conditions including hyperthyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism, which can lead to symptoms like palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder leading to hypothyroidism that can, in rare cases, present with hyperthyroid phases (Hashitoxicosis) potentially causing palpitations and hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: A condition that can cause post-nasal drip. It can indirectly affect other bodily functions, exacerbating symptoms like palpitations in hyperthyroid patients.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Nodule
diagnoses.description: Can cause hyperthyroidism if the nodule is producing thyroid hormones, possibly leading to palpitations.

diagnoses.name: Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis
diagnoses.description: A rare disease that can affect many organs, including the thyroid, potentially leading to hyperthyroidism and associated symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Congenital Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Though primarily leading to hypothyroidism, compensatory mechanisms or incorrect treatment can lead to hyperthyroid symptoms such as palpitations; associated with hearing loss in severe untreated cases.

diagnoses.name: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection
diagnoses.reason: HPV is a common cause of warts.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: The presence of obstructive sleep apnea is diagnosed based on the described symptom.

diagnoses.name: Klinefelter Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: This condition can lead to delayed puberty and may also be associated with monocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Turner Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: A genetic disorder that affects females, leading to delayed puberty and potentially other complications.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reason: Chronic kidney disease can lead to a higher risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs) and may sometimes result in monocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection
diagnoses.reason: A urinary tract infection is identified based on the described symptom.

diagnoses.name: Hypogonadism
diagnoses.reason: A condition related to delayed puberty, which can be a primary or secondary condition affecting hormonal levels.

diagnoses.name: Constitutional Delay of Growth and Puberty (CDGP)
diagnoses.reason: A common cause of delayed puberty not associated with any systemic disease.

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency disorders
diagnoses.reason: Certain immunodeficiency disorders can lead to more frequent infections (such as warts and UTIs) and may be related to monocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reason: In females, PCOS can lead to delayed puberty and is also associated with a higher risk of developing obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: COVID-19
diagnoses.reasoning: COVID-19 can cause dysosmia (loss of smell) and dysgeusia (loss of taste) as common symptoms. It can also lead to secondary bacterial infections such as otitis media. Hypersensitivity reactions are also possible.

diagnoses.name: Viral upper respiratory infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Common cold or other viral infections can lead to otitis media as a complication, can affect the senses of smell and taste, and may trigger hypersensitivity reactions or skin issues like dyshidrotic eczema due to immune response.

diagnoses.name: Allergic rhinitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Allergic rhinitis can cause hypersensitivity reactions and can be associated with otitis media due to eustachian tube dysfunction. Rarely, it might affect smell and taste or lead to skin reactions.

diagnoses.name: Zinc deficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Zinc plays a pivotal role in taste and smell functions; its deficiency can cause dysgeusia and dysosmia. It also affects the immune system, potentially exacerbating skin conditions like eczema.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren’s syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth but can also affect other exocrine glands, possibly leading to dysgeusia, dysosmia, skin disorders like eczema, and heightened immune responses.

diagnoses.name: Eczema (Atopic Dermatitis)
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily a skin condition, severe eczema can affect overall immune function, lead to hypersensitivity reactions, and be associated with secondary infections like otitis media.

diagnoses.name: Contact dermatitis
diagnoses.reasoning: A condition primarily of the skin but can signify a systemic hypersensitivity reaction. Might indirectly affect other symptoms through the stress of dealing with the skin condition.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Poorly controlled diabetes can lead to a compromised immune system, affecting smell and taste, possibly inducing skin issues like infections or eczema, and increasing the risk of otitis media.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: Compromised immune system can lead to a myriad of symptoms, including those affecting taste and smell, increase in infections such as otitis media, hypersensitivity reactions, and various dermatological conditions.

diagnoses.name: Hay fever (Allergic rhinitis)
diagnoses.reasoning: Besides causing hypersensitivity reactions, allergic rhinitis can sometimes affect the sense of smell and taste, potentially exacerbating conditions like dyshidrotic eczema due to allergen exposure.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Toxic ingestion (such as certain poisons or heavy metals)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome

diagnoses.explanation: Common cold often includes nasal congestion as a symptom.
Allergic rhinitis can lead to symptoms like nasal congestion.
Non-allergic rhinitis involves chronic sneezing or having a congested, drippy nose with no apparent cause.
Influenza (flu) can cause nasal congestion among other symptoms.
Sinusitis can cause nasal congestion, sometimes leading to further complications.
Dehydration can sometimes contribute to or exacerbate symptoms of hypotension and in some cases may affect urinary function.
Autonomic neuropathy can affect nerves that regulate the bladder and blood pressure, leading to incontinence and hypotension.
Although not directly causing hypotension or nasal congestion, a severe UTI can lead to systemic symptoms and indirectly affect blood pressure.
Adrenal insufficiency can lead to hypotension and, indirectly, some level of incontinence due to weakness.
This rare condition involves autonomic failure, including bladder control issues and significant blood pressure drops upon standing.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms before the head pain begins.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, causing symptoms that may include numbness and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. A TIA doesn't cause permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A result of damage to the nerves outside of the brain and spinal cord (peripheral nerves), often causing weakness, numbness, and pain.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur if you have diabetes. High blood sugar can injure nerves throughout your body.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can lead to neurological problems and anemia. Symptoms may include weakness, tiredness, numbness, and tingling.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain or close to your brain. Various types of brain tumors exist.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders of the thyroid gland can lead to various symptoms, including changes in weight, energy levels, and neurological complaints.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C associated vasculitis
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis in absence of other explainable causes)
Vasculitis, such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
